newsitem.title: BELGIUM: UK women win prize for "disarming" Indonesian jet.
newsitem.headline: UK women win prize for "disarming" Indonesian jet.

text.p: Four British women were awarded an international peace prize on Wednesday for disabling a British military jet that they alleged would be used by the Indonesian government against civilian protesters in East Timor.

"One of the causes of repression in Indonesia is the sale of arms by Britain, Germany, France, the United States and other countries," East Timor human rights activist Jose Ramos-Horta told the ceremony in the European Parliament as he presented the prize.
"The action of these four women is an inspiration to all of us," the co-holder of the 1996 Nobel Peace Prize added.

Horta on Monday appealed to the European Union and the United States to freeze weapons sales to the government of President Suharto, warning, "From a strategic point of view, it is extremely dangerous to provide weapons to a dictatorship that is under challenge".
The four women were awarded the prize -- named after Nobel Laureate Sean Macbride -- by the Geneva-based International Peace Bureau (IPB), of which Macbride was a former president.
The women broke into a British Aerospace factory in Lancashire, north England, in January 1996 and attempted to disable a jet.

Andrea Needham, one of the four, told the ceremony that people in the West, who had freedom to speak out where the East Timorese people could not, had a duty to call their governments to account for supporting repressive regimes.
Indonesia invaded the former Portuguese colony of East Timor in 1975 in a unilateral act still not recognised by the United Nations.
